previewParagraphs: Two teams with contrasting routes through the League Stage meet with plenty still on the line: Sparta Praha’s high-control approach faces an Aberdeen side that has learned to live on narrow margins and tidy structure.

The League Stage picture makes the contrast clear. Sparta Praha sit in the top cluster with 3 wins, 1 draw and 1 loss, scoring 7 and conceding just 3 for a +4 differential. Aberdeen are buried deeper at 0 wins from 5, two draws to show for it, and an 11 against tally that has hurt their goal difference.

Form across all competitions adds nuance. Sparta’s last six reads 4 wins, 1 draw and 1 loss, with 1.67 goals scored and 1.33 conceded on average. They generate 15.83 shots per match and keep the ball for 67.67%, so the pattern is familiar: pressure, territory, and enough creativity to tilt most contests.

Home data is the wrinkle. Over the last three at their place across all competitions, Sparta have gone 0 wins, 2 draws and 1 loss despite averaging 21.67 shots and 76.67% possession. That said, their league-specific home profile remains robust, with 4 clean sheets in their last 7 Conference League home matches and 6 unbeaten in their last 7 at home in this competition.

Aberdeen arrive with a sturdier near-term run across all competitions than their League Stage record suggests. Their last six show 3 wins, 2 draws and just 1 defeat, averaging 1.67 scored and 1.17 conceded, with 15.5 shots and 5.17 on target from a 51.83% share of the ball.

On the road across all competitions, Aberdeen have stayed unbeaten in 5 of their last 6 and claimed 7 clean sheets in their last 17 away outings. There is resilience, though they have also lost by 2 or more in 5 of their last 12 away matches, a sign that when they do crack, the margin can widen.

The League Stage trend tells a harsher story for the visitors. Aberdeen are winless in 13 of their last 16 Conference League matches and have lost 50% of their last 14 in this competition, with 50% of their last 10 ending level. It is a sequence that explains their current placement despite some recent upticks elsewhere.

Sparta’s broader body of work is stronger. They have been unbeaten in 80% of their last 10 Conference League matches and have won 57% of their last 7 at home in this competition, including 4 wins by 2 or more in that span. Across all competitions, they are undefeated in 80% of their last 15 and have won 55% of their last 40 overall.

Stylistically, this could hinge on Sparta’s ability to convert sustained pressure into cleaner chances. Their volume is rarely in doubt, but Aberdeen’s comfort in a compact shape plus quick wide outlets has improved. Set pieces and transitions for the visitors versus structured circulation and wingback thrusts for the hosts frame the likely dynamic.

Squad notes matter for Sparta. Angelo Preciado and Jakub Martinec are unavailable, as are Magnus Kofod Andersen, Vojtech Vorel and Dominik Hollý, which pushes Pavel Kadeřábek and Matěj Ryneš into prominent wing roles and keeps the Asger Sørensen led back three intact around options like Jaroslav Zelený and Patrik Vydra.

previewParagraphs: Two unbeaten runs meet with very different personalities. Shakhtar have been purring along with the ball, Rijeka thriving without it. The result should hinge on who bends first: possession or pragmatism.

Shakhtar reach this stage in assured form and with the numbers to match the eye test. In the Conference League league stage they are 4 wins, 0 draws and 1 loss, scoring 10 and conceding 5 for a +5 goal difference, good for second place after five matches. Across their last six in all competitions they are 4 wins, 2 draws and 0 losses, averaging 2.83 goals for and just 0.5 against with 67.67% possession and 6.83 shots on target per match.

Their home levels have been even more assertive. Over the last three home matches in all competitions Shakhtar are 2 wins, 1 draw and 0 losses, with a striking 4.67 goals scored per game, 7.33 shots on target and 69.67% possession. Bigger-picture trends back that up: they have not been defeated in 27 of their last 30 matches in all competitions, and they are unbeaten in 9 straight. At home, 85% of their last 40 have finished without defeat, and 50% of their last 12 home wins came by 2 or more goals.

Rijeka arrive with a different profile but similarly positive momentum. Their league stage card reads 2 wins, 2 draws and 1 loss, five scored and only two conceded for +3 and 14th place, a defensive return of 0.4 goals against per game. In the last six across all competitions they mirror Shakhtar’s results at 4 wins, 2 draws and 0 losses, scoring 2.67 and conceding 0.5 on average while operating with 41.33% possession and 5.17 shots on target per match.

The split in approach is clear. Shakhtar’s control game routinely produces territory and shooting volume, while Rijeka prefer a compact block and quick surges through the middle third. Rijeka’s recent streaks are notable: three consecutive wins, each by 2 or more goals. They also have been undefeated in 10 of their last 12 matches in all competitions (83%).

There is a caveat away from home for the Croatian side. Rijeka are winless in 5 of their last 6 away matches in all competitions (83%), and 50% of that run ended level. Against a side that regularly tilts the pitch, that away trend could matter, especially if Shakhtar again reach their usual 6 to 7 shots on target at home.

Tactically, this shapes as 4-1-4-1 or 4-2-3-1 for Shakhtar, with two playmakers between the lines and energetic wide midfielders pinning back full backs. Rijeka’s best work has come from a 4-2-3-1 that keeps distances tight, trusting the double pivot to clog central lanes and spring the front four into space.

Individual battles should be decisive. Shakhtar’s midfield trio of Oleg Ocheretko, Dmytro Kryskiv and Pedrinho has balanced control with penetration in recent weeks, while Newerton and Lucas Ferreira offer direct running from the flanks. Lassina Traoré provides a traditional reference point up front and a target for early crosses.

For Rijeka, Tiago Dantas sets the rhythm at the base, with Niko Janković and Amer Gojak offering vertical passing and late entries into the box. Width from Toni Fruk and Luka Menalo stretches back lines, and Ante Matej Jurić works the channels. The defensive axis of Stjepan Radeljić and Ante Majstorović has been stingy in this league stage, part of a unit that has allowed just two goals in five matches.

previewParagraphs: Two teams with similar records but very different rhythms meet with qualification nuance hanging in the air. Sigma’s slide contrasts with Lech’s measured consistency, and the numbers hint at a cagey contest where small margins could decide everything.

Both clubs sit on 7 points after five UEFA Europa Conference League league-stage matches, but the paths have differed. Sigma Olomouc are 22nd with 2 wins, 1 draw and 2 losses, scoring 6 and conceding 7. Lech Poznan are 20th with the same 2 wins, 1 draw and 2 losses, yet a stronger goal profile at 10 for and 7 against. The table says even; the trend lines say otherwise.

Recent form for Sigma has been rough. Over the last six in all competitions they have 1 win, 1 draw and 4 losses, averaging 0.83 goals scored and 2 conceded. Their overall shot production sits at 12.83 attempts per match with 3.33 on target, alongside 49.33% possession. The bright spot comes from their last three at home in all competitions, where they posted 2 wins and 1 loss, scoring 1.33 and conceding 0.67 with improved 4.67 shots on target from 13 total attempts, even if possession dipped to 42.67%.

Lech arrive on a steady run. Across their last six in all competitions they are unbeaten with 3 wins and 3 draws, scoring 1.83 and conceding 0.67 on average. Their shot profile is strong at 13.83 attempts and 4.83 on target per match, and they have controlled the ball at 55.17%. That blend of volume and defensive restraint has underpinned their 100% unbeaten streak across those six.

Comparing the underlying numbers, Lech’s attack has the higher ceiling with 10 league-stage goals from five matches and better chance creation lately. Sigma’s recent defensive tightening at home matters, though, especially given those 0.67 goals conceded across their last three home outings in all competitions. The game state could favor a controlled tempo, with Lech’s 55.17% possession average meeting a Sigma side comfortable without the ball.

The trends add important context. Sigma have lost each of their last 4 in all competitions and are winless in 4 straight. Yet at home they have kept clean sheets in 58% of their last 12 and have been undefeated in 83% of those 12, winning 6. It is a profile of a side far more resilient on their own pitch than their recent overall skid suggests.

For Lech, resilience travels. They are undefeated in 16 of their last 20 away matches in all competitions and have posted 13 clean sheets across their last 32 away fixtures. In all competitions they have been undefeated in 80% of their last 15. League-specific numbers show a strong backbone too, with 16 undefeated in their last 20 Conference League matches, though they have also lost 3 of their last 6 in the competition, hinting at occasional volatility.

Personnel could tilt fine margins. Sigma are without Yunusa Muritala, removing a direct outlet in transition. Lech lack Patrik Wålemark and Daniel Håkans, while Luis Palma is suspended. That pushes creative burden toward Ali Gholizadeh and Leo Bengtsson in support of Mikael Ishak, with Pablo Rodríguez linking play. For Sigma, craft and control fall to Radim Breite and Michal Beran, while Jáchym Šíp and Artur Dolznikov must supply the final-third spark.

Tactically, both sides have leaned on 4-2-3-1 in their recent samples. Sigma’s recent home data suggests a compact block and selective pressing, while Lech’s structure should emphasize ball circulation and diagonal service to the flanks. Set pieces and second phases may be decisive given the expected territorial balance.

previewParagraphs: Two contrasting blueprints collide as possession-hungry Rayo Vallecano face compact and resilient Drita, with both sides eyeing a clean finish to the league stage and a result that fits their signature styles.

Rayo Vallecano arrive with a mixed run in all competitions across their last six outings, recording 1 win, 3 draws and 2 losses. The numbers outline the balance of their game: 0.83 goals scored and 1 conceded per match, underpinned by 59.33% possession and 13.83 total shots, 4 of them on target. At home, the performance looks steadier across the last three, with 1 win and 2 draws, 1.33 goals per game and a hefty 20.33 shots per match, suggesting territorial control tends to translate into pressure, if not always volume of goals.

Drita’s last six in all competitions read 2 wins, 2 draws and 2 defeats, with a symmetrical 1.33 goals for and 1.33 against. Shot creation is lean at 7 attempts per match and 2.67 on target, backed by 43.67% possession. The immediate trend is less favorable, though, as they are winless in their last 3 in all competitions.

Within the Conference League league stage, Rayo have posted 3 wins, 1 draw and 1 loss from 5, scoring 10 and conceding 7 for a +3 differential. Drita have been harder to break down than their ranking implies, going 2 wins, 2 draws and 1 loss with 4 goals scored and 5 conceded. The contrast is clear: Rayo’s games open up with more chances and scoring, while Drita’s are low-margin affairs where defensive structure dominates.

Rayo’s league-stage averages sit at 2.0 goals for and 1.4 against per match, while Drita’s stand at 0.8 for and 1.0 against. That gap in chance creation is echoed by Rayo’s recent league metrics, where they have played with roughly 63% possession and around 6 shots on target per match, and by their overall six-game sample in all competitions that shows sustained control of the ball and territory. Drita’s output is slimmer, but they typically keep games close on the scoreboard.

Rayo’s body of work is nuanced. In all competitions, they have drawn 4 of their last 8 and are winless in 6 of their last 7. Yet their league form is stronger, with 5 wins from the last 7 and they haven’t been defeated in 6 of those 7 in the Conference League. At Vallecas, the base is solid: undefeated in 11 of their last 12 home matches in all competitions, drawing 8 of the last 15 and keeping clean sheets in 6 of 15.

Drita’s resilience shows up repeatedly. In all competitions, they haven’t been defeated in 13 of their last 16, and away from home they haven’t been defeated in 9 of their last 11, with clean sheets in 3 of the last 7 away. In the Conference League, they’ve won 7 of their last 14 and are undefeated in 6 of their last 7. The current wrinkle is form: despite those sturdy trends, they are winless in their last 3 in all competitions.

previewParagraphs: Two teams heading in different directions meet with group-stage clarity starting to bite. Celje have shown a knack for control and chance creation, while Shelbourne are hanging on through structure and resolve. The balance of power looks clear on paper, but the scenarios within 90 minutes are more nuanced.

Celje’s last 6 in all competitions reads 2 wins, 1 draw and 3 losses, with 1.33 goals scored and 1.33 conceded on average. The numbers improve significantly at home across the last 3, where they are unbeaten with 1 win and 2 draws, averaging 19 total shots, 6.33 on target and 60.33% possession alongside 1.67 scored and 0.67 conceded.

Shelbourne’s recent sequence is more strained. Over their last 6 in all competitions they have 1 win, 1 draw and 4 losses, scoring 0.5 per match and conceding 1.5, with 42.17% possession. Their forward output has been light and that feeds into their continental story so far.

Within the Conference League group stage, Celje have posted 3 wins, 0 draws and 2 losses from 5, with 8 goals for and 7 against. The profile fits a side that dictates phases and creates steady pressure. Shelbourne sit at 0 wins, 1 draw and 4 losses from 5, still seeking their first goal of the group after conceding 7. They come in on a run that includes 3 straight defeats in all competitions and winless in their last 4 in all competitions.

Broader context strengthens Celje’s case. They are undefeated in 16 of their last 20 matches in all competitions, and in this competition they are undefeated in 10 of their last 12 at home. Those baselines contrast with Shelbourne’s league-specific trend of being winless in 80% of their last 10 Conference League matches, a sign of how hard they have found it to climb in this environment.

Celje rank 12th in the League Stage with 3 wins, 0 draws and 2 losses, scoring 1.6 per game and conceding 1.4, for a +1 goal difference across 5. Shelbourne are 34th with 0 wins, 1 draw and 4 losses, no goals scored and 1.4 conceded per match for a -7 differential. The contrast in attacking threat is stark.

Celje bring consistent pressure metrics: across their last 15 in all competitions they average 4.33 shots on target and 53% possession, and in the last 6 they have 56.5% possession with 4.17 shots on target. Importantly, they have won by 2 or more goals in 40% of their last 10 Conference League matches and kept clean sheets in 42% of their last 12 home matches in all competitions. Their home profile is reliable.

Shelbourne’s data indicates resilience but limited bite. In all competitions they have lost 50% of their last 8 and are winless in 83% of their last 6, while in the Conference League their last 10 show 2.2 shots on target per match on 39.7% possession. Away from home in all competitions, 6 wins across the last 12 suggests they can scrap results, yet recent streaks matter: they have lost their last 3 in all competitions and are winless in their last 4 in all competitions.

previewParagraphs: Pressure and opportunity share the same stage here. Legia Warszawa carry a rough run yet remain capable of a one-match reset, while Lincoln Red Imps arrive with momentum but a leaky record at this level. The balance between form and level of opposition should shape a tight contest.

Legia’s Conference League campaign needs a push. In the League Stage they sit on 1 win, 0 draws and 4 losses with 4 goals scored and 7 conceded, which is 0.8 for and 1.4 against per game. Lincoln are better placed at 2 wins, 1 draw and 2 losses, though a 6 to 11 goal tally hints at risk, with 2.2 conceded per match.

Recent form in all competitions tilts the mood. Legia’s last 6 across all competitions show 0 wins, 2 draws and 4 losses, averaging 0.67 scored and 1.5 conceded, with 12.17 shots per match and 4 on target from 48.33% possession. The volume is there, but the conversion rate is hurting them.

At home, the last 3 in all competitions read 0 wins, 1 draw and 2 losses, 0.67 scored and 1.33 conceded, with 11.33 shots and 3.33 on target from 51% possession. The streaks are stark too: they have lost their last 3 matches and are winless in 11 of their last 11 in all competitions. Yet in this competition specifically, they have managed 10 wins across their last 20, and 42% of their last 12 home Conference League outings ended in clean sheets, a reminder that their ceiling at home remains higher than the current slump suggests.

Lincoln Red Imps bring sharper short-term results. Their last 6 in all competitions show 4 wins, 1 draw and 1 loss, at 2.83 scored and just 1 conceded, producing 8.17 shots, 4 on target, and only 37.83% possession. They have been direct and efficient, a profile that travels well.

Their away body of work in all competitions is robust: wins in 68% of their last 40 away matches, undefeated in 16 of their last 20 away, and 47% of their last 15 away victories have been by 2 or more goals. However, their Conference League record is a different story, with 8 losses in their last 12 in the competition, winless in 12 of their last 15, and 12 losses by 2 or more in their last 19 at this level. Stepping up in class has exposed them defensively.

Tactically, Legia have alternated between 4-2-3-1 and 4-1-4-1. Expect a front four built around the direct running of Ermal Krasniqi and the work rate of Paweł Wszołek, with Mileta Rajović offering a penalty-area presence. They average 12.17 shots but only 4 on target in their last 6 across all competitions, so shot quality and set-piece execution could be decisive.

Lincoln typically line up 4-4-2, compact off the ball and quick into the channels. With limited possession, their shot accuracy matters; 4 on target from 8.17 attempts in their last 6 suggests they do not waste much. The flip side is the Conference League concession rate of 2.2 per match in the League Stage, which leaves them vulnerable if they sit too deep for too long.

Numbers point to a scoreline with chances both ways. Legia’s current league-stage average of 1.4 conceded meets a Lincoln unit that has punched above its weight in all competitions, yet the visitors’ historical struggles in this tournament carry weight. If Legia reach their home defensive baseline from previous Conference League campaigns, they will give themselves a platform.
